title: How to Make a Thermos

steps.headline: Rinse out a 2 L (2.1 US qt) plastic bottle with soapy water.
steps.description: You can use a new 2 L (2.1 US qt) bottle or reuse one that had another drink in it. Put a squirt of liquid dish soap in the bottle and fill it ¼ full with hot water. Screw on the cap and shake the bottle to clean it out. Rinse out the bottle with clean water until you don’t see any more soap. Old soda bottles work well for making a thermos. Avoid using smaller bottles since it won’t be able to fit the inner bottle.

steps.headline: Cut the neck off of the bottle with a utility knife.
steps.description: Lay the bottle sideways so it’s easier to cut into. Place the blade of your knife about 3–5 centimetres (1.2–2.0 in) down from the top of the cap. Carefully push the blade of the knife into the bottle and use a slight sawing motion to cut around the bottle. Rotate the bottle as you need to so your knife doesn’t slip. Recycle the neck of the bottle when you finish the cut. It doesn’t matter if you make the cut perfectly straight.Warning: Utility knives can easily slice through plastic, so be mindful of where you hold the bottle so you don’t cut your fingers.

steps.headline: Split the bottle in half to separate the top and bottom.
steps.description: Keep the bottle laid on its side so it’s easier to cut. Place the knife so it’s about 10–13 centimetres (3.9–5.1 in) from the bottom of the bottle so the blade is parallel to the other cut you made. Push the blade carefully into the plastic and pull it slowly around the circumference of the bottle. Hold the bottle steady with your nondominant hand so it’s easier to cut, and rotate it as needed. If the bottle has a label, remove it so you can cut through the bottle easier.

steps.headline: Wrap a 1 L (1.1 US qt) glass bottle with 2 layers of aluminum foil.
steps.description: Get a glass bottle with a small mouth and a resealable cap so you can use your thermos multiple times. Rip off a sheet of aluminum foil large enough to wrap around the entire glass bottle. Press the foil as tightly as you can around the glass bottle and tape it in place. Put another layer of foil over the first for added layers of insulation. The aluminum foil will help insulate the inner bottle as well as create a reflective surface so cold drinks don’t warm up from the sun as quickly. You can buy empty glass bottles online or from some kitchen supply stores.Warning: Do not use plastic bottles for the inside of your thermos since they are not manufactured to handle hot liquids or be used multiple times.

steps.headline: Glue the glass bottle inside the bottom half of the plastic bottle.
steps.description: Turn on a hot glue gun and let it heat up completely before using it. Hold the glass bottle upside down with your nondominant hand and the glue gun in your dominant hand. Make a zigzag pattern of hot glue on the bottom of the glass bottle to get even coverage. Quickly press the glass bottle inside the bottom of the plastic bottle and hold it in place for 30 seconds. You don’t have to glue the glass bottle to the bottom of the plastic bottle, but your bottle will be sturdier if you do. Hot glue dries quickly, so work as fast as you can so it adheres properly.

steps.headline: Feed the glass bottle’s neck through the top half of the plastic bottle.
steps.description: Position the top half of the plastic bottle over the glass bottle. Push the top half of the plastic bottle down as far as you can until the cut edge along the top presses against the glass bottle’s neck. Make sure the cap on the glass bottle sticks out from the hole you cut in the plastic bottle earlier so you can easily drink from it. If the glass bottle neck doesn’t fit through the hole at the top of the plastic bottle, then trim the plastic bottle with your utility knife.

steps.headline: Use hot glue to secure the top of the plastic bottle to the glass bottle.
steps.description: Hold the top of the plastic bottle firmly against the glass bottle’s neck so there aren’t any gaps and keep it in place with your nondominant hand. Use your dominant hand to apply a generous layer of hot glue around the top edge of the plastic bottle. Continue holding the plastic bottle in place until the glue sets, which should take about 30–60 seconds. If there are still gaps between the top edge of the plastic bottle and the glass bottle’s neck, apply more hot glue to fill them in. You can also wrap 2–3 layers of packaging tape around the edge if you don’t have any hot glue.

steps.headline: Wrap packaging tape around the middle of the plastic bottle to secure the halves.
steps.description: Make sure the packaging tape overlaps the top and bottom halves of the plastic bottle so it can create an airtight seal. Guide the tape around the bottle and press it tightly against the plastic to seal it. Continue wrapping around the bottle 2–3 times with the packaging tape so it doesn’t come undone or break. You can also try using duct tape to help seal the bottle.

steps.headline: Pour hot or cold liquids into your thermos using a funnel.
steps.description: Avoid pouring the liquid directly into the bottle since you could easily spill and loosen the tape around your thermos. Put the narrow end of a funnel into the glass bottle and slowly pour your drink inside. Be careful not to overfill the funnel, or else it could spill out. Pull the funnel out of the bottle and seal the cap on the bottle to use your thermos. Avoid using the thermos for anything with solids, such as soups or stews, since the food could get stuck inside.

steps.headline: Drink from the thermos like a regular bottle.
steps.description: When you want to use your thermos, take off the cap and take a sip. You can also pour your drink into another cup if you don’t want to drink directly from the thermos. If you’re drinking a hot liquid, test the temperature of your drink before taking a big sip so you don’t accidentally burn your mouth. Thermoses can keep drinks hot for many hours, so always be sure to check the drink temperature on your lips or with a finger beforehand.

steps.headline: Clean the thermos out with soapy water after each use.
steps.description: Rinse the thermos out with warm water first to remove any liquid that’s inside. Put a squirt of liquid dish soap in the thermos and fill it halfway with warm water. Shake the thermos to clean the inside before emptying it out. Finally, rinse the thermos out with clean water until you don’t see any more suds. Place the thermos upside down to drain and dry. Rinse out your thermos as soon as you finish what’s inside to reduce the risk of bacteria growing.Warning: Don’t submerge the thermos or put it in the dishwasher since the tape will come undone.
